We don't have it in the hands of the individuals.
And that's this case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, he was arrested for speeding, wasn't he?
I mean that's part of--

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --You don't challenge the probable cause for that arrest?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: For the arrest for speeding?
No.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: How about the arrest for marijuana?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Not for the arrest for the marijuana.
As to the interior of the car, not for the packages in the car.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, the issue in this case is bottomed upon the premise that the arrest was a lawful custodial arrest.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: That's... yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Is it not?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: And the only issue is whether or not the search and seizure were within the permissible scope of a search and seizure incident to that lawful custodial arrest?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
And I think that it is.
It falls into two categories.
As to the petitioners, it falls into whether or not it comes within Chimel, which is grabbable reach.

As to the Government, it falls within whether or not you are going to expand Robinson and in effect subsume Chimel by saying, as long as you're arrested, the police have the right to search the area, whether or not the materials in the area are within the grabbable reach of the individual.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now, did Chimel speak in terms of "grabbable reach" or "reach"?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
It said--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Or was the emphasis on plain view, first?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: --No.
The emphasis, I believe, Your Honor, with all due respect, was the area immediately associated with the arrestee into which he could reach.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And in plain view?
But--

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: No, there wasn't... I do not believe there was a mention of plain view.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: --Plain view comes first.
You don't know whether it's within reach, grabbable or otherwise, until you see it.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: No, I might indicate that in Chimel the opinion covered closed drawers, open drawers; plain view, not in plain view; many areas.

What I'm suggesting is that if we were to adopt the government's side of this, we would be extinguishing Chimel, because we wouldn't have to concern ourselves anymore with whether or not there was a grabbable reach problem; we would simply say, in the vein of Robinson, are you arrested?
Does that in fact cause a breach of your privacy?
If so, is it just incidental to search the matters around you?
That was what was rejected by the court of appeals below because that was the finding of the appellate division here.
There has never been a finding that these materials came within the Chimel grabbable reach.
As a matter of fact, the--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, that's the issue before us.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: --Yes, it was never argued at the time of the trial.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Is this within the permissible geographic scope of a search incident to a lawful custodial arrest?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: There's no question, is there, about the permissible temporal scope?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: I don't think so at all here; no, not in this particular--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: There is no question, at least by hypothesis, that this was a lawful custodial arrest?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: --That's true.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: So the only issue is whether or not this is within the permissible geographic scope of such a search--

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, and I--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: --and seizure.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: --What I am suggesting is that we should not... and the Court has not, in the past... adopted a place or area requirement, but has in fact employed this grabbable reach element.

And if we take the precedent of this Court simply from the Chimel standpoint, it's not only not established by the petitioners in this case, it's not even remotely established by the facts in this case, since, as indicated, the officer did something that would show that by following the procedure here, he's certainly not deprived of any law enforcement activity, because he in fact took the jacket with him; had the people to such a degree of control that they first stopped at the police barracks, then they went on to the court; the same individuals are with him.
He had it, as he said, in his possession and secured.
So we're not in any way attempting to frustrate law enforcement.
We're simply saying when you're not within the Chimel confines, then you have it in your possession; take it to a magistrate.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, the issue is whether or not this was within the Chimel confines.
That's the only issue before us.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
And I think that that is true unless we were to attempt to argue the Government's version, which is, forget about Chimel.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Cambria, may I ask you a question?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir, Justice Powell.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: If this jacket had been on the seat beside the driver, it would have been reachable before the driver got out of the car.
Under the right to search incident to arrest, if the driver was still sitting at the steering wheel the officer I take it could then have searched the jacket, if it lay on the seat beside him.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: At the time of arrest the occupant was outside of the car.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: I know.
But my question assumed he was--

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: If it was within his grabbable reach, under Chimel, I think that I would be foolish to argue otherwise.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: --So that the difference really is whether or not the officer asked for the jacket before or after the driver stepped out of the car?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: No, I don't think that that's the difference.

I think the difference is that at the time the people were placed under arrest and again, recognizing the two bases for Chimel, was there a basis for believing destruction of evidence or a danger to the officer?
And was that manifested by the jacket being within the grabbable reach of the arrestee?
That was the actual issue.

Because the Court has never said that for any type of arrest, when it's not within the Chimel reach, that you can simply search the entire area, search all of the possessions, or even the car, for that matter.

So what I'm indicating is, the critical time, as this Court has repeatedly said and most recently in Sanders is at the time of the arrest and at the time of the search; that's when we measure the facts.
And as I'm indicating, here when we measure the facts, as the court below obviously interpreted the record... and the record itself is clear, the state has not carried their burden.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Do you not draw any distinction between a residence, a home, and an automobile?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: I don't think that there is a distinction between articles within an automobile and articles in a residence, or articles anywhere else, if they are private receptacles, and I don't think there's much argument here that these are not, then the question is, as it was in Sanders and the other cases, that we don't give up the privacy simply because they happened to be in an automobile or because they're somewhere else.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What do you do with our Edwards case then, which said that although the search took place an hour and a half after the arrest or two hours after the arrest, since it could have been done at the time of the arrest, it was good at two hours afterwards?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: I think that there is a vast difference between Edwards and this case, because in Mr. Edwards' situation we're talking about his clothes, which were totally immediately associated with him because he was wearing them.
There was, therefore, a great jeopardy that the paint flakes which were on the clothes could have been destroyed by him, which was the very evidence that they were attempting to preserve in the case.
So there was a vast difference between this case and that case.
In that case, if we take one of the two forks of Chimel, which is preservation of evidence immediately associated with the person, Edwards falls directly within that.

If we take my case, where the material is immediately associated with the police officer and at no time after the arrest and search associated with my client, then we have none of the two-pronged basis for Chimel.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You certainly have the temporal disparity in Edwards that you do not have here and that you don't have in Chimel.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I don't think we have a temporal difference in Edwards since, one is he was wearing the garment, it was always in danger of having whatever evidence was contained on it being destroyed.
So it was a contemporaneous search, no matter what had happened, until you separated the individual from the clothing.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, so then it makes no difference when the person is arrested?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: No, it would make a difference under Preston, certainly.
That would be an additional factor, one that's not involved here but one that was involved in Preston, which was also involved in Edwards.
I mean, I would say that that is another ground upon which to invalidate a search and seizure, if there's a temporal variation, difference; which we don't have.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Except in Edwards, it was held that it would not invalidate it.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: No, it did not invalidate it, and I submit, because of several unique factors.
One was, apparently they didn't have any clothes for the man until sometime... it was late at night, and they had taken him down to the cell; that was their normal procedure to do that.
And again, the evidence was apparently clinging to his very outer garments at all times, and they... at least the way I read that case... acted as quickly as possible under the circumstances.
So the time was really not a factor because it was a constant jeopardy, whereas, certainly, here there is nothing like that at all.
As we have indicated, maybe with regard to these facts the officer had the jacket, readily admitted it, at all times.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Cambria, maybe this is too trivial a question, but you have used the term "grabbable reach" repeatedly.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is a grabbable reach a greater or a lesser area than a just plain reach?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think that grabbable reach, in the sense of being able to reach the materials, that's the way I interpret Chimel; readily reach the materials immediately.

The words are used, immediately, ready at reach, ready to hand, are some of the other words that have been used, which I think is much different than this situation, but there's never been a claim, by proof, that any of this was ready to hand, at any time.
And of course, that's the way the court of appeals saw it below, and it is my contention that based upon the record that we have here, not very... pardon me?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, have we got to go through the record to find out if it was reachable or not?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: I think that the record certainly shows in all ways and fashions that it was not, and there is no affirmative proof that it was.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Was there any findings?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Never.
There was never any findings in this case that it was within the grabbable reach.
It was never mentioned at one time by any court that it was within the grabbable reach.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, but that's not... in a sense, a constitutional fact, if we're talking about a Fourth Amendment claim.
If there was no finding, we are entitled to make our judgment on that.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think that... it seems to me that in this particular case you couldn't make a judgment of fact, that the Court would not be in a position to make a judgment of fact as opposed to a judgment of law based upon the record as found by the highest court of the State of New York.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, if the Court of Appeals of New York said, this was not within grabbable reach--

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: It did.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Whereabouts in the record?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: The opinion was to the effect that in the last footnote of the chief judge's opinion he said, we search the record in vain in an attempt to find the facts which support, the dissenting justice is Gabrielli, his statement that this was ready to hand or within their reach.
It isn't there; nowhere.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, do you regard that as a finding of fact?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

I think that when it appears in a majority opinion and they... as perhaps this Court in its majority opinion in talking of certain things mentioned in dissents, when you say, we have in essence construed the record and we find no proof whatsoever that this is within the grabbable reach, I think that's a finding of fact.

Because on the other hand, if they would have found to the contrary, then I feel they would have been bound by Chimel, and they have discussed Chimel, clearly, and said that it simply did not come within the confine of Chimel.
I think it is most certainly a finding of fact in this case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Cambria, I take it that when you arrest someone in connection with a car, if you want to go beyond your grabbable reach range, you'll have to rely on the automobile search, the automobile theory, which requires probable cause to believe that where you are searching you may find what you're searching for?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: And then only as to those items listed by this Court in Opperman, which would be items immediately associated with a car: trunk, glove compartment, wheel wells, fender wells, and so on.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I think you also have to have probable cause to believe you're going to find something in those areas.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: No question about it.
I think there's no doubt about it.
There has to be a pleading situation, plus there has to be the limited expectation of privacy as to the areas being searched, and certainly not packages which are within the car itself.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Cambria, when you... as I understand the facts here, after the officer stopped the car, the driver rolled down the left window of the car, and the officer when he went into the back seat was on one side of the car and the four individuals were on the other side.
Were they on the left side or the right side of the car?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: No, the only testimony here is that he took the individuals out to the rear of the car, that he first split them up and patted them all down.
He went back into the car, found some minor--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Which door did he go in, do you know?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: --He, I believe, indicated the driver's door.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: He went in the driver's door.
I see.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Then he came back out--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But if the window was open, I suppose it's conceivable, even though they're outside the car, they could have reached in and grabbed the jacket.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: --However, the record doesn't support that.
The record has them at the back of the vehicle and in no way supports going into the car.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: No way... in fact, the officer puts himself back into the car.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: I thought the four individuals were separated from one another.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: That's so.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Are they all behind the car?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: That's what the record states, Your Honor, yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Mr. Cambria, let me go back to the footnote that you have referred to in Chief Judge Cooke's opinion, at A-81 of the Appendix.
He says,
"One searches the record in vain for support of the dissenter's claim that at the time of arrest... the point from which the predicate for the warrantless search is measured #. "
Then he goes on,

"Indeed, the facts, as found at the suppression hearing and affirmed by the Appellate Division, were to the effect that the jacket was searched after the defendant was removed from the vehicle and then placed under arrest. "

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Now, that suggests more the exclusive control type of thing that the Government is arguing against, rather than the grabbable reach thing.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: I think, in this case, that the court of appeals decision can be read to say, since it was in the exclusive control of the officer and it was not within the grabbable reach of the defendants, then it doesn't fit within the Chimel doctrine.

And I think that's exactly what that footnote stands for, by saying, we have it in the police officer's possession which, under Chadwick and Sanders, he should therefore take it down to and have the magistrate examine it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you agree with the United States, I gather, if the court of appeals, if the opinion below is read as establishing a control test, you don't defend that?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: That established a control... if there would have been testimony in this case that the material was within the grabbable reach of the individuals, it would be a different case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I know.
But if a man is carrying his jacket when he gets out of the car and they arrest him and the officer takes his jacket from him, then it's under the complete control of the officer.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Of the officer.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, if the court below meant that you couldn't search that jacket, you do not defend that view?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: I see this... I see no reason to defend it on this record.
I believe that it could be defended under Chadwick and Sanders, but I do not see the reason to do it here.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Neither Chadwick nor Sanders involved, and I think you'll agree with this, a claim that the search was incident to a lawful custodial arrest, did it?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: It was discussed.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: It was discussed in Chadwick.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: And the findings were made... and discussed in a footnote, I guess, in Sanders?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the finding was made that the statement was made in Sanders that the argument could not have been validly made because this was a locked thing in a locked trunk.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: I believe it was unlocked, but it was in a trunk and the trunk was opened and the individuals were outside.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Therefore it was not within the geographic vicinity.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: It was not within the Chimel reach; yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Right.
And that in Chadwick the statement was made that it was not within the temporal--

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: --Confines of Chimel, so the argument could not have been... or the search and seizure could not have been supported as a search incident to a lawful arrest.
But neither case involved the claim that it was, did it?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I think that it does not... they did not, they do and they don't... they do from the standpoint of the fact that it was a consideration which was available, it certainly gave pause to this Court--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: The argument was not made in either case.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: --I submit that it wasn't made because it wasn't a valid argument to be made.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, the opinions of the court indicate that the various arguments--

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: That it was not a valid argument.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: --would not have been valid.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: We are in a better position than that case.
There we have the arrestees standing by the trunk at the time, two of them, and this unlocked briefcase is pulled out of an open trunk, at that time.
My case is entirely different than that.
We have people outside and he's inside, and so on.
And so that's why.
But I say this, Sanders and Chadwick are involved to the degree that we have to deal with the Government's argument which is, just the arrest alone gives you the area or the zone of search.
I say it does not because under Chadwick and Sanders we have a privacy expectation in these articles.
The petitioner's case, of course, deals with Chimel squarely.
And as I've indicated, the record does not support their claim at all.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If we were to deal with the consent issue, that was not decided by, or treated by the court of appeals in New York, was it?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: No, it was not raised, and it finds no support in the record.
One of the clarifications I might make is that it was after the time of the discovery of the cocaine that the officer then said, whose jacket is this?
And that's when there was a disclaimer.
But he had already conducted his search prior to the time he elicited--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Search of what?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: --Search of the jacket itself.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Yes, yes.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: Then, later on, of course, there's a direct claim of ownership.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What was the statement made about the back?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: The back, Your Honor?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The trunk.

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: No, there was no statement.
In the Robbins case there was a statement made about--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Any comparable statement like that here?

turn.speaker: paul_j_cambria_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Cambria, Jr.
turn.text: --Nothing at all in this case.
At all.
Nothing at all.
Thank you very much, Your Honors.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Harvey.

turn.speaker: james_r_harvey
turn.label: Mr. James R. Harvey
turn.text: Since I still have a couple minutes, Your Honor, if it please the Court:
The only point I would make is that the Chimel criteria as set forth by the Court defines the area as the area that the arrestee might reach in order to grab a weapon or evidentiary material.
And I think that's here, certainly, in this case on the record on certainly one of two theories.
Either the overpowering theory, and I think quite frankly that's the theory that's here clearly on the record below--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If we take your view, I take it that any container in a car, any piece of evidence in a car, or in the interior of the car, or anything in any container in the car, is searchable and seizable incident to the arrest?

turn.speaker: james_r_harvey
turn.label: Mr. James R. Harvey
turn.text: --My position, Your Honor, under the facts of this case, where you've got four individuals exiting the vehicle, all being placed under arrest for possession of marijuana, that anything--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It wouldn't have made any difference... to you it wouldn't have made any difference whether the jacket was on the floor, or the back seat, or anywhere in the interior of the car, or whether what the officer seized was a briefcase?

turn.speaker: james_r_harvey
turn.label: Mr. James R. Harvey
turn.text: --If it were within the area of gaining access by any of these arrestees, Your Honor, then it should be subject to--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: If it was a briefcase in exactly the same position as the jacket, you would say it could be searched?

turn.speaker: james_r_harvey
turn.label: Mr. James R. Harvey
turn.text: --A briefcase that could be gotten into, yes, Your Honor.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, wait a minute, you've said, under the overpowering theory, or your said, under--

turn.speaker: james_r_harvey
turn.label: Mr. James R. Harvey
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, also they could have reached in through the... that it's tied in.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: --The overpowering theory would depend, I suppose, if I understand your shorthand for the theory, upon how many arrestees there were and how many policemen there were arresting them, and which ones were--

turn.speaker: james_r_harvey
turn.label: Mr. James R. Harvey
turn.text: I think that's certainly the criteria, and the area that's being searched, in this case the inside of an automobile, Your Honor, that is, on the back seat of the--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: --The overpowering theory depends at least in part, I suppose, upon the fact that there was one arresting officer and four arrestees.
Doesn't it?

turn.speaker: james_r_harvey
turn.label: Mr. James R. Harvey
turn.text: --The facts of this case; that's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: And therefore if there were only one arrestee, then he might--

turn.speaker: james_r_harvey
turn.label: Mr. James R. Harvey
turn.text: You're getting into a different factual situation.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: --And there's a possibility of overpowering when you leave four of them in the back of the car?
Behind the car?
You're going to get in the car.

turn.speaker: james_r_harvey
turn.label: Mr. James R. Harvey
turn.text: You're certainly in the car looking through the vehicle in this case, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Yes, but I mean, that's a danger of being overpowered?
You left four of them back there all by themselves.

turn.speaker: james_r_harvey
turn.label: Mr. James R. Harvey
turn.text: In fact--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And you got in the car and got back out, and nothing happens.

turn.speaker: james_r_harvey
turn.label: Mr. James R. Harvey
turn.text: --In fact, the--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Then you've got to worry about overpowering?

turn.speaker: james_r_harvey
turn.label: Mr. James R. Harvey
turn.text: --In fact, the officer was not overpowered in this particular case, but he certainly, under the Chimel-Robinson rules had the opportunity and the right to search the interior of those jackets, Your Honor.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
